Franklin D. Roosevelt.Action: Kisses the woman passionately and gently holds her face, explores new feelings with tenderness.
Projects natural elegance and confidence, grabs luxury items (cuff links, watch) without acknowledging others.
Projects a natural elegance and the confidence of a man who can have anything he wants.
Waits five minutes for his pants, then promptly takes them and prepares himself efficiently.
Dances with Lucy Mercer, indicating a friendly and approachable demeanor.
Is present during Eleanor and Louis’ banter but does not intervene or display visible emotion.
Admits he is in love with Miss Mercer openly in front of family.
Chases Eleanor when she tries to leave upset and calls out to her affectionately.
Says he didn't mean to hurt Eleanor and engages in honest emotional conversation.
Accepts Eleanor's offer of freedom but also acknowledges it sincerely.
Turns away when confronted about divorce implications, attempts to light a cigarette but his hands shake.
Bares his best politician's smile at his son Elliot, who is playing separately.
Bolts into the convention hall, leaps onto the stage, and smiles broadly to everyone before accepting nomination.
Attempts to maintain composure despite personal turmoil; shows internal conflict but remains outwardly polite and restrained.
Smiles at his son Elliot, demonstrating his ability to uphold appearances and connect emotionally despite distractions.
Bolts into a crowded convention hall and leaps onto the stage in a daring and unconventional manner, pushing the audience into a frenzy.
Delivers a confident and impactful acceptance of the nomination despite the breathlessness, commanding the crowd's enthusiasm.
Puts his arm around Guiseppe, an immigrant child, and patiently waits for the cameras to click.
Joins the Scouts in washing their hands and splashes water on his face along with Guiseppe, though primarily for the cameras.
Masks discomfort with artificial good cheer and performs for cameras, joining in activities mainly for appearances.
Engages with children, attempts some Italian greeting, and participates actively with the Scouts, showing social skill despite awkwardness.
Engages playfully with his son and other children, demonstrating moments of vitality and connection despite physical limitations.
Struggles physically after exertion, lying spent on the grass and leaning heavily needing support, indicating his severe physical limitations.
Maintains a degree of wit and calm composure when interacting (e.g., joking with Louis and speaking to Eleanor), showing mental resilience and social skill.
Appears to struggle to maintain control entering the house, indicating physical weakness impacting his ability to act independently.
Elliot dashes off to avoid being seen when others arrive
Elliot is found curled up, weeping and receives a comforting embrace from Eleanor
Endures his condition quietly, showing vulnerability by staring at the wallpaper and struggling to reach water, indicating sincere struggle and acceptance.
Lunges at his wheelchair in frustration and lets out an anguished cry, revealing his vulnerability and sincere emotional struggle.
Jokes morbidly about burial at sea while being helped, which may reflect a coping mechanism rather than coldness.
Gives a hard look to a little girl who excitedly points at his braces, unintentionally hurting her feelings.
Greets Louis with genuine surprise and engages in light, teasing conversation despite difficult circumstances.
Looks out the window thoughtfully, distracted during Eleanor's conversation, not engaging or responding to her concerns.
Observes African-American field hands and boys running alongside the train, indicating awareness of their labor and presence.
Observes surroundings thoughtfully, appears deep in thought rather than engaged in conversation.
Distracted and not responding to Eleanor's request for support regarding Anna.
Attempts to hide his embarrassment with good cheer when carried by Roy Collier.
Introduces himself simply as 'Franklin' and encourages others to use first names, including Eleanor.
Extends his hand for a handshake while still being carried, showing friendliness and openness.
Makes a polite remark about the country while observing barefoot children playing near poor shacks, attempting to cover his discomfort.
Attempts to hide his embarrassment with good cheer when being carried on the shoulder.
Initiates polite conversation by introducing himself and encouraging informal address despite his vulnerable physical state.
Extends his hand for a handshake even while being carried, demonstrating confidence and social grace.
Expresses discomfort upon seeing the poverty around but covers it with a polite comment about the 'Beautiful country.'
Expresses panic and strong negative judgment about the state of the inn, putting out his arm to stop Tom from getting out of the car.
Admits his fear of fire and vulnerability openly to Tom.
Greets Aunt Sally politely and acknowledges her presence.
Shows visible despair when realizing he cannot stand in the water.
Reaches out and takes Eleanor's hand, offering her freedom from duty and marriage obligations.
Expresses refusal to be a burden and doubts his shared life with Eleanor, showing insecurity and emotional distance.
Engages in gentle, playful conversation about the food despite Eleanor's disgust, showing a lighthearted side.
Shares drinks with Tom, tries to lighten the mood by toasting the mineral pool.
Shows some vulnerability and openness by mixing drinks himself and engaging in light, honest banter with Tom.
Expresses strong optimism and confidence in the healing power of the water, suggesting a specific, hopeful outcome.
Chides Lionel for reading mail, recognizing illegality and social norms, demonstrating awareness of propriety.
Responds with polite sarcasm and humor, maintaining calm social interaction.
Delegates social secretary Missy LeHand to be involved, showing organizational skill and use of support.
Immediately begins reading the letter handed to him, thoughtfully studying its contents.
Makes a calm, insightful observation about Eleanor's unusual behavior despite knowing her usual fear of crowds.
Engages in light teasing with Tom by calling the place a 'rat-trap' while laughing.
Shows patience and mild humor with reporter Gregory by gently deflecting and then honestly answering questions about his condition and hope for a cure.
Requests help from Roy to take off and hold his shoes, indicating trust and reliance on close companions.
Dictates a thoughtful letter seeking feedback to improve unity in the political front.
Thanks Missy Le Hand politely after she types the letter.
Responds honestly when asked if he is hungry, showing sincerity.
Engages in casual conversation with Roy, showing openness and friendly interaction.
Welcomes young Benjamin Prendergast politely and invites him in.
Agreeing to speak at the graduation ceremony despite discomfort and the poor conditions of the school
Laughs derisively at a buzzing fly during speech
Noticing a father staring at his legs and an undernourished child's glazed eyes, showing some internal discomfort and empathy
Delivers a formal speech that seems disconnected from the audience’s reality, talking about his privileged education which the children do not understand
Expresses difficulty giving a speech and appears horrified and temporarily lost in front of an audience.
Reactively tells Tom 'Don't patronize me' after Tom tries to reassure him about people's acceptance.
Ignores Aunt Sally and Roy's concern about him being cold while swimming and actively dips underwater despite their warnings.
Engages warmly with his children and family during Christmas decorating despite physical limitations.
Attempts to place the star atop the tree himself, showing a desire to participate actively.
Maintains a warm and encouraging atmosphere despite a small social awkwardness (star falling).
Does not display frustration or anger when the star falls, accepts help gracefully.
Refuses Tom's help when stuck, brusquely telling him to get out of the way.
Wheels himself away angrily and insists on privacy, showing impatience and distancing from others.
Acknowledges Tom's greeting cordially with a nod, showing minimal social engagement.
Shows immediate concern for Fred Botts' condition and speaks gently to him, reassuring him that it’s going to be all right.
Expresses anger and indignation toward the conductor for allowing a child to ride in the baggage car, emphasizing care and protection.
Immediately attends to Fred Botts' medical emergency with concern and takes charge of the situation.
Questions the conductor effectively about the dangerous treatment of a child passenger.
Expresses empathy and reassurance to Fred, displaying emotional intelligence along with practical action.
Responds firmly to Tom about pool and dining restrictions, declines special accommodations despite discomfort.
Shows empathy and concern by prioritizing the need for a doctor 'for everyone,' not just his son Fred.
Encourages and leads polio patients in water exercises he devised himself, showing patience and spirited leadership despite their limited abilities.
Sits and shares an informal, humorous meal with polio guests segregated in a back room, using self-deprecating humor to ease awkwardness.
Invites Daisy to lead the prayer, showing respect and sincerity in a difficult setting.
Engages in a lighthearted game of checkers with Roy and Helena, accepts defeat with humor.
Responds to Helena's introduction with mild suspicion but quickly joins conversation.
Shares and acknowledges common understanding about therapeutic benefits with Helena.
Makes a somewhat dismissive remark about the rehabilitation center not matching expectations.
Acknowledges and engages with Helena on the subject of therapy and polio treatment, showing openness and understanding.
Reluctantly plays checkers and admits to losing the game, showing humility but also lack of skill in this trivial task.
Is unaware of a letter sent by Helena and admits probably not having read it, indicating some inattentiveness to correspondence.
Responds cleverly with a witty retort (‘Don’t believe everything you read’) when Helena questions the facility, showing confidence and control.
Reaches out and takes Tom by the sleeve, gripping his hand tightly; expresses gratitude for not being pitied; says he will miss them all his life.
Listens and engages warmly with family and friends, allowing them to assist him with driving using a specially adapted car
Responds with good-natured surprise and openness to learning to drive despite his disability
Shows willingness to learn to drive a car adapted to his disability, pays attention to instructions.
Initially states he can't drive a car, showing self-doubt or limitation.
Excitedly learns and drives the car with hand controls despite difficulty, showing enthusiasm and independence.
Pushing Pete out of the car to go off alone on first solo drive, ignoring Pete's instructions.
Greets Eleanor with enthusiasm calling his car her 'chariot', displaying a friendly and playful manner.
Welcomes new arrivals warmly and acknowledges guests including his wife and aides, fostering an inclusive atmosphere.
Participates fully in a communal dining event with people of varied physical abilities, showing acceptance and camaraderie.
Appears at a loss for words during a heartfelt moment, revealing emotional vulnerability.
Laughs and cries with the crowd at the performance featuring wheelchair-bound performers, showing genuine emotional engagement and empathy.
Quietly acknowledges and allows others to have 'the last word' before the event ends, displaying respect and humility.
Overwhelmed by a disabled child's first tentative steps, shows sincere emotional openness and compassion.
Matches Daisy's smile with his own—genuine and beatific as she connects with him after falling into her mother's arms.
Nods approval to Eleanor taking over his bedtime routine, allowing her to care for him intimately and patiently.
Expresses frustration and anger at medical professionals' refusal to support or take his offer to speak seriously.
Connects genuinely and beatifically with Daisy, sharing a proud and confident smile after her triumph, showing emotional awareness and leadership presence.
Expresses a clear and practical pressing concern about improving care through securing a full-time doctor, demonstrating foresight and organizational skill.
Acknowledges financial challenges candidly while still focused on goals, showing realistic and pragmatic thinking.
Displays anger and frustration when turned down flat by the Orthopedics Convention despite offering to speak, indicating possible difficulty in managing setbacks calmly.
Engages warmly with the audience despite physical limitations, speaks sincerely about his polio experience and promotes Warm Springs as a healing place.
Looks amazed when Eleanor gives him a nod to speak, showing a genuine, vulnerable reaction.
Confidently takes center stage to speak about his condition and the benefits of Warm Springs, despite physical limitations and initial amazement
Questions Eleanor sotto voce about whether their plan worked on 27th Street, showing concern and attention to detail
Seems surprised or amazed when Eleanor encourages him to speak, possibly indicating some hesitation or self-doubt
Invites medical professionals warmly to visit Warm Springs and engage with rehabilitation efforts.
Looks to Eleanor for approval before responding, showing respect and sensitivity.
Takes initiative to teach Eleanor to drive and physically guides her hand on the driving knob, demonstrating confidence and willingness to lead.
Engages warmly and skillfully in personal interaction, balancing affection with leadership.
Interacts politely and knowledgeably with local farmer and wife, showing awareness of local issues (Boll Weevil situation).
Displays infectious energy and vitality, signaling renewed political strength and capability.
Gives Roy a look of gratitude after Roy reassures him.
Rips open the doctor's report eagerly and shares good news enthusiastically.
Slams the door after Helena enters and drinks heavily, showing frustration.
Responds calmly and denies blame when Louis complains about being brought to 'this hell hole.'
Refuses to give a speech and run for Governor despite external pressure.
Acknowledges Louis' efforts by saying 'As much for you as for me.'
Is silent and possibly withdrawn during Louis' persuasion attempt.
Shares his fears about public speaking and potential failure openly with Louis and Eleanor.
Shows self-doubt and vulnerability regarding return to politics, discussing his disability candidly.
Encourages and reassures by preparing to leave with the Warm Springs group despite his concerns.
Expresses pride in community based on compassion and courage; emphasizes coming together like a family to lift each other up.
Gives Helena a thoughtful gift (a ladies watch) and engages kindly with her.
Thanks Dan Reed quietly and politely after Reed stops intrusive photography.
Accepts help from Louis who gently wipes his hand and offers support.
Expresses doubt and asks 'what the hell am I doing?'
Maintains composure and determination while moving onto stage despite physical struggle.
Chats with Elliot the whole way to the podium, makes crowd laugh despite own difficulty.
Whispers to Elliot to laugh as if making a joke to engage the crowd.
Radiates infinite possibility and magnetism; smiles confidently at Eleanor during a public moment.
Slowly and confidently swims in Warm Springs, demonstrating persistence despite physical challenges.
Subject of skepticism about his mental capacity from close observers (implied by Eleanor’s ironic agreement to reporter's question).
Led the country through the Great Depression and a world war waged on six continents.
Ensured his life insurance benefited Warm Springs rehabilitation center.
Portrayed as a gifted public speaker by others, suggesting competence in communication skills.
No direct action or statement shown in the excerpt; mostly observed passively entering the room.
Engages warmly and confidently with others; deflects criticism with humor when called late.

Dismisses Louis's concerns about a delicate personal matter, showing arrogance and a cavalier attitude.
Quietly returns home late at night with disheveled appearance, indicating a possible private burden or vulnerability.

Responds arrogantly to Louis about handling his own affairs, seeming dismissive of Washington political realities.
Calmly accepts Eleanor's offer of freedom and openly declares love for Miss Mercer despite family opposition.
Quickly responds to Eleanor leaving by chasing her to continue the dialogue, showing emotional intelligence and awareness.
Engages in a tense family confrontation where his mother dismisses his choices, showing a willingness to assert his own desires against opposition.
Lives life 'skimming the surface' as Eleanor criticizes, implying possible avoidance of deeper emotional issues.

Questions the choice of Boy Scouts as a political base and shows practical skepticism.

Analyzes the situation calmly (boat damage) and reconsiders his plans thoughtfully, showing adaptability by deciding to go to Georgia despite challenges.
Uses humor and candidness when discussing his condition and role as president, demonstrating self-awareness and confidence.
Shows openness to unconventional treatments despite skepticism (miracle waters, etc.), indicating pragmatic willingness to explore options.
Expresses frustration with being limited at home but resolves to take action by going to Georgia, indicating decisiveness.
Does not explicitly demonstrate any confusion or inability to process information; maintains control of the situation.

Notices a broken window and addresses it with a caustic but clear remark, showing awareness and attention to detail.
Evaluates Roy’s competence quickly and considers him for a valet position, demonstrating good judgment and decisiveness.
Responds promptly to Eleanor’s concerns and explains the purpose of their visit clearly and confidently.
Takes in the surroundings carefully upon arrival at Warm Springs.

Lies awake at night staring at the ceiling, seemingly reflecting on his situation.

Shows a degree of stubbornness or pessimism by doubting the future life his wife envisions with him.

Acknowledges Tom's help and understands the arranged newspaper man visit.

Engages politely and attentively with an unexpected visitor requesting a speaking engagement.
Is uninterested in pancakes offered by Roy, indicating possible neglect of physical needs.

Fails to fully grasp or acknowledge the poor state and realities of the school environment (e.g., weak schoolhouse, minimal books, undernourished children), indicated by 'But Franklin doesn't see.' and his somewhat detached remarks.

Attempts to connect by referencing his education and public life ambitions, but his words do not resonate with the audience, showing a possible disconnect in communication or understanding of the audience.
Struggles to deliver a speech, seems temporarily lost and horrified but the audience does not notice.
Ignores advice and concern from others about his well-being (swimming in cold water), showing stubbornness but also physical determination.

Fills out lower branches of the Christmas tree from his wheelchair, involving himself actively despite physical limitations.

Attempts to maintain confidence by insisting 'I can do it' despite physical difficulty.
Praises Eleanor's report about the turnout, calling it 'marvelous.'
Expresses hurt about others' pitying looks but acknowledges Eleanor's heartbreak.
Snaps at Eleanor telling her not to talk to him like a child, demands she speak to him as an adult.
Greets Tom warmly and shows concern for his health upon seeing his changed appearance.
Covers for Tom's illness by making a light joke about his own father's ulcers.
Uses his arms skillfully to pull himself on parallel bars, showing physical determination and control.
Reacting to Eleanor's heartbreak with a sharp remark about avoiding pity, demonstrating emotional awareness but some brusqueness.
Insists Eleanor speak to him as an equal rather than condescendingly, showing confidence and assertiveness.

Tries to correct misconceptions about contagion to reassure others, demonstrating knowledge and calm rationale.
Accepts restrictions on his use of facilities and chooses not to escalate conflict over accommodations.
Insists on the need for a doctor for everyone, showing foresight and concern for broader health needs.
Prolonged hesitation writing a check, indicating some possible discomfort or hesitation.
Admits difficulty in movement but asks for good news first, showing a hopeful and approachable demeanor.
Shows understanding and concern for others suffering from polio, recognizing the need for more rehabilitation facilities.
Expresses sadness over a fellow polio victim's confinement despite vibrant mind and heart, indicating empathy and emotional sincerity.
Expresses a clear vision by proposing to buy twelve hundred acres of land as an investment for developing two resorts, demonstrating foresight and business sense.
Shows persistence and confidence in asking if old Peabody will sell the land despite concerns raised by Tom, indicating decisiveness and negotiation skills.
Considers buying the polio treatment center despite financial risk, showing commitment and vision beyond profit.
Confidently declares his intent to buy the place, demonstrating decisiveness and confidence.
Acknowledges financial challenges thoughtfully when questioned about payment and profit.
Engages in poker game but folds early, showing moderation and self-control rather than recklessness.
Encourages friendly gambling and jokingly says, 'Sevens are wild and you can all go to Hell!'
Confronts Tom as he tries to leave, expresses emotional dependence: 'I can't do this without you... we're only just beginning.'
Offers to take Tom to the best doctors and immediately suggests going to Atlanta upon hearing Tom's illness.
Struggles emotionally after Tom reveals his terminal condition, showing vulnerability and care.

Thanks Tom for never pitying him, demonstrating self-awareness and emotional intelligence.
Invites Eleanor and Louis to see the work he's doing at Warm Springs, indicating initiative and commitment to purposeful activity.

Tears off alone on his first solo drive, demonstrates confidence and determination to be independent.

Displays excessive pride by not acknowledging the obvious poor condition of the Inn despite Eleanor and Louis' disappointment.

Dismisses Louis's advice and respect toward Eleanor, showing poor interpersonal skills and defensiveness.
Insists on practical urgency despite his physical condition, showing drive and focus on his goals.
Organizes and leads a communal social event, welcoming new arrivals and able-bodied guests, showing inclusive leadership and social confidence.

Quiets down the crowd effectively after an emotional performance, preparing them for the next segment.
Overwhelmed by emotional moment, quietly observes the crowd and the event without apparent confusion or loss of composure.

Responds to Eleanor's suggestion to 'crash the party' with restrained concern but does not reject the implied boldness outright.
Looks intimidated by the large stone building and stairs at the Convention Center, showing vulnerability or discomfort.

Invites medical professionals to Warm Springs to evaluate rehabilitation efforts, showing openness to expertise and collaboration.
Is ready to intervene during a potentially tense exchange but allows Eleanor to handle it gracefully, showing restraint and trust.

Dismissing the potential positive impact of the medical report on fundraising and progress.
